elements.label: Church of St Michael the Archangel
elements.description: Atop the belfry, an iron archangel pins a coiled serpent beneath his foot; below, Red Army surgeons have turned his church into a makeshift hospital. But the surgeons do not blunt pain with morphine, and the soldiers who leave their care often leave with fewer limbs than when they arrived.

elements.label: Trenchant Cell
elements.description: The Jesuits came in the 17th century and built their college here, on the banks of the river. Then came the fire, Alexander's ban on the order, another collapse, and ten years of neglect. Now it is a prison under the hand of the Byelorussian military department. One of the cells, the warden says, is off-limits due to safety concerns. But those who share the warden's devotions are allowed to spend a night immured within the cell, to meditate with the knife before a stone basin that faces the western window.

elements.label: Tower Luchinskaya
elements.description: The Red Army has taken up garrison in the old fort, and its proudest tower now houses arms for the soldiery. The tower's topmost room, which stores explosives, is watched at all times by a guard rotation - except, those permitted above know there are no such explosives. The only weapons kept therein are the kind that knew service before gunpowder was fielded in war. Contemplate the spear, the sabre, the staff, and chill your blood with their experience.

elements.label: Shrine to the Cavalry-Monk
elements.description: In the days of Old Rus, a warrior-monk from Bryansk met a champion of the Golden Horde at Kulikovo, and each man, supposedly, killed the other. Old soldiers like to pass around another version of the story, where the dead monk went on to kill a dozen Mongols more after his enemy's spear pierced his heart. The monk's body was borne to Moscow, but his spear and his saddle are kept in reverence here, in the secret rooms of a veteran's club.

elements.label: Shell-Scarred Monument
elements.description: The statue of the Grand Prince on the hill has been disfigured by shelling. The cross-staff in his hand, now missing its head, ends in a jagged point; only half his face remains unscored by flying shrapnel and gunfire. But still, soldiers come by night to make offerings at the base of his monument: wine, seized weapons, the ears and hands of German soldiers.

elements.label: Disciplining Grounds
elements.description: A failed dynamiting after the Revolution left this flour mill abandoned and unsafe, and the proprietor's suicide on the premises has given rise to a haunted reputation. But a band of certain Red Army soldiers enjoys the seclusion. Every seventh night, they gather under the old masonry to train themselves in the arts of severity and lethality.

elements.label: Repurposed Cathedral
elements.description: The Party dismantled the cathedral in 1930 as a part of their efforts to stamp out the old religion. Its domes were destroyed and its bells removed, and its bones were given to the city as a warehouse. Still, a group of servicemen have raised icons in a hidden room, but the icons honour a power that isn't quite God. As far as I know, God was never so scarred in any of his depictions.

elements.label: Bunker-Chapel
elements.description: The mining tunnels under the city have become air raid shelters. Lanterns are necessary to walk safely, but there is one chamber below where light is not permitted. Here, in the reverent dark, soldiers daub their blood on the old stone and sleep, dreaming of a god with a scarred face.

elements.label: Fane of the One-Armed
elements.description: An abandoned grain silo has been adopted by a secret cult honouring an odd hero: the one-armed Briton who stormed the city for the White Russians, alone in a single tank. Perhaps he is now a Name. Perhaps he's only dead. But those who venerate the Colonel remember him.

elements.label: Face of the Premier
elements.description: Under the ceiling of a derelict iron foundry lies a massive, hollow head in the likeness of Stalin himself. Turned on its side, his empty eye has become a door, and within someone long-gone has etched grim secrets on the interior of his skull.

elements.label: Soldier's Orchard
elements.description: Buried here, in rows of iron crosses next to a now-trampled orchard, were fifty brave Russian soldiers. I say 'were' only because the graves where their bodies must have laid are now all vacant. Grave robbers? Grave robbers seldom take the whole body.

elements.label: Ascetic's Cave
elements.description: Hidden in the winter wood this cave therein lies in a perfect silence. Something lingers within. The echo of a slain soldier? A forgotten histid? If I go down into the dark, I won't be able to see whatever it is - but perhaps I don't need to.

elements.label: Unfinished Game
elements.description: In a soundless grove where the wind stills, a chessboard has been carved into the top of a large, flat rock. Chess pieces of bone are arrayed upon the board. Whoever was playing here never finished their game - perhaps they were ambushed, or perhaps the players decided chess was too calm a contest by which to settle their dispute. Edge-Long can be like that.
